title: 111_s1612
content: The Employee Stock Ownership Plan Promotion and Improvement Act of 2009 exempts certain S corporation distributions from a 10 percent penalty tax if they are made on stock held by an employee stock ownership plan. This amendment applies to distributions made after the enactment of the Act. The ESOP Dividend Exception exempts certain S corporation distributions from a penalty tax if made to an employee stock ownership plan. The amendment exempts ESOP dividends from penalty tax for S corporation distributions to employee stock ownership plans established before March 15, 1991, effective for taxable years after December 31, 1989. Refunds or credits resulting from this amendment are not subject to limitations. The amendment allows for refunds or credits of tax to be made if prevented by law within 1 year of enactment. The amendment related to Section 1042 allows for refunds or credits of tax within 1 year of enactment. The amendment to Section 1042 allows for tax deferral on sales to an ESOP sponsored by an S Corporation and permits reinvestment in certain mutual funds. The amendment made to Section 1042 allows for tax deferral on sales of qualified securities after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a modification to the 25-percent shareholder rule under section 409(n)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to modify the 25-percent shareholder rule under section 409(n)(1) for certain transactions involving employer securities. The amendment made by paragraph (1) will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. SMALL BUSINESS AND EMPLOYEE STOCK OWNERSHIP. Congress finds that since 1974, many small businesses in the United States have transitioned ownership to an employee stock ownership plan (ESOP). Data shows that ESOP-owned small businesses provide significant benefits to employees and communities. Small businesses that qualify for preferences under the Small Business Act lose their eligibility if 50 percent or more of the business is acquired by an ESOP on behalf of employees. This change in ownership disqualifies the business, even if all other criteria remain the same. The Small Business Act is amended to address disqualification of small businesses if 50% or more is acquired by an ESOP solely because of the acquisition. SEC. 44. EMPLOYEE STOCK OWNERSHIP PLANS. In this section, an ESOP is defined as an employee stock ownership plan, and an ESOP business concern is a small business concern where 50 percent or more is acquired by an ESOP. An ESOP business concern can still be considered a small business if a majority of shares and control are held by individuals who meet necessary criteria. The amendments made by this section specify that for an ESOP business concern to be eligible for a loan or program, control must be with ESOP shareholders and comply with tax requirements. Effective date is January 1 after enactment of the Act.
